label.text: Desalination
Large scale desalination plants produce freshwater from salty seawater.
One technique used in these plants is reverse osmosis.
Reverse osmosis involves forcing seawater onto a semi-permeable membrane. The membrane only allows small, non-charged particles to pass through.
This process produces freshwater and a highly concentrated salt solution (brine). Brine is commonly released into rivers or the sea.
Which type of particle will pass through the semi-permeable membrane?

A typical river system has freshwater upstream. The estuary is where the river meets the sea and freshwater mixes with salty seawater.
Which one of the following conclusions best describes what would happen to the number of aquatic species if brine was added to a river or the sea?
There would be no effect if it was added to the seawater with a concentration of 37 g/L salt.
If added to freshwater, it would only affect the number of freshwater species.
The greatest change in the number of species would occur if brine was added to estuarine water.
Adding brine to any part of a river system would eliminate all the freshwater fish.

All of the following statements about desalination are true.
Which statement justifies the use of desalination plants to allow all people equal access to essential resources?
Desalination plants provide a reliable source of freshwater, ensuring that water supplies for manufacturing can be maintained.
Desalination technology has been proven to work: almost 16,000 desalination plants are operating in about 177 countries.
The environmental impact of desalination units can be reduced if carbon-neutral energy sources are used and the disposal of brine is carefully managed.
Use of desalination plants can provide water security for regions of the world where water scarcity can lead to poor hygiene and increased rates of disease.

Increasing the saltiness of freshwater (upstream) will greatly reduce the number of all types of aquatic species whereas increasing the water in an estuary in more likely to cause an increase in the number of most aquatic species.

Operating desalination plants is expensive.
Which one of the following is a reason why costs are reduced if desalination plants are located close to where freshwater is needed?
It avoids the need to protect the local environment.
It reduces the energy needed to power the desalination plants.
It increases the productivity of the workforce.
It reduces the distance over which the freshwater is pumped.

Scientists propose that communities should focus on water conservation as a strategy to overcome water shortages.
What is one way that communities can conserve water?
build a desalination plant
install rainwater tanks
use groundwater
provide free bottled water
